repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
:{range}lua executes the specified lines in the current buffer as
Lua code, regardless of its extension or 'filetype'.

Close #27103

comment_data.body: If `[range]` and `{chunk}` are mutually exclusive, I would expect `:[range]lua` and `:lua {chunk}` to each be documented in separate paragraphs (cf. `:help :read`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -242,10 +242,12 @@ The Lua print() function redirects its output to the Nvim message area, with
 arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
 
                                                                   *:lua=* *:lua*
-:lua {chunk}
-    Executes Lua chunk {chunk}. If {chunk} starts with "=" the rest of the
-    chunk is evaluated as an expression and printed. `:lua =expr` or `:=expr` is
-    equivalent to `:lua print(vim.inspect(expr))`.
+:[range]lua {chunk}

comment_data.body:
Nice. I think splitting this out made the usage easier to understand at a glance.

Note you have a typo ("aso" -> "as") and `[range]` doesn't usually appear in bars in the documentation as far as I can tell, and should be `{range}` if the range is required, as it is here. I'm also not sure if you really need to comment on the `'filetype'`/extension. I understand that this addition is overcoming a limitation of `:source`, but as a user, this commentary is a bit odd without knowing that context. How about simply the following?

```suggestion
    Executes the specified lines as Lua code.
```

Vim's docs often use "the specified lines" to refer to a range.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
:{range}lua
```

Since the range is required for this usage.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua

comment_data.body:
> and [range] doesn't usually appear in bars in the documentation as far as I can tell

`|[range]|` is an alternative link for the `cmdline-ranges` help, so I think it's worth keeping.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body:
> but as a user, this commentary is a bit odd without knowing that context. 

Why? This is the only reason we even need `:{range}lua` in the first place. Pointing that out doesn't seem odd.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body: Ah, no, that's not the only reason. You might want to evaluate a snippet in a Lua file as well (e.g., for simple debugging of a condition in a script).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body: But you can already do that with `:[range]source`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body: Fair; in this case this is indeed useful information -- but it might be even more useful to make explicit the comparison to `:source` (e.g., "unlike `:[range]source`, this evaluates the selected lines as Lua independent of `'filetype'`")?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body: Yeah that's what I was thinking as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,10 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:[range]lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer aso Lua code, regardless of
+    its extension or the current |'filetype'|.

comment_data.body:
Let's use the same phrasing as https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4e59422e1d4950a3042bad41a7b81c8db4f8b648/src/nvim/eval/typval.h#L441

```suggestion
      semsg(_(e_invarg2), "{chunk} or [count] is required");
```
Remove this `<`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,6 +253,11 @@ arguments separated by " " (space) instead of "\t" (tab).
         :lua print(_VERSION)
 <    To see the LuaJIT version: >vim
         :lua =jit.version
+
+:{range}lua
+    Executes the |[range]| in the current buffer as Lua code. Unlike |:source|,
+    this will execute the specified lines regardless of the extension or
+    |'filetype'| of the buffer.
 <

comment_data.body: Oh oops, not remove but place this block below it right?

         :lua =jit.version
 <

comment_data.body: I don't think this is a good idea, because both `{chunk}` and `{range}` can be specified, which needs to be rejected.

Go with the previous phrasing then? Or just

    either {chunk} or {range} is required

Or do we need more distinct errors, both

    {chunk} or {range} required

and

    only one of {chunk} and {range} allowed
`exactly one of`? That's clearer and satisfies both cases.
Works for me. Is there no precedent for this kind of message?
Hmm, `nvim_create_autocmd` has two separate error messages for mutually exclusive `command` and `callback`. `setloclist()` and `setqflist()` too.

comment_regular_data.body: should we update the "lua interface" section of `:h vim-differences` here? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4e59422e1d4950a3042bad41a7b81c8db4f8b648/runtime/doc/vim_diff.txt#L494

Related #7177

This sort of conflicts with #7177 as having both will be quite confusing.

> This sort of conflicts with #7177 as having both will be quite confusing.

Good point. This PR is more important though:

- useful for `:help` buffers
- piping _buffer text_ to `:lua <code>` isn't very convenient because `vim.firstline` and `vim.lastline` are verbose to type out, thus it's uncommon. Whereas executing a Lua snippet is very common.

If there is a strong use-case for `:{range}lua foo(vim.firstline)` we can always enable that behavior when both are present (though it's a bit clever/confusing as you noted).

title: feat(ex_cmds): support ranged :lua
